summary: Silver miner Daniel Plainview (Daniel Day-Lewis) leads a hardscrabble life with his son, H.W. (Dillon Freasier). It often feels like achieving success in America is primarily predicated on A's ability to influence B to support the same plans or ideas that will most benefit A, regardless of the actual impact or effect these plans or ideas will have on B.

This struggle for our focus and attention comes in many forms and from many angles, in a relentless barrage day after day, much of it totally unnoticeable to us as it is happening. We have not only allowed and accepted this behavior but have come to expect it from nearly all facets of society, creating a breeding ground for the widespread cases of greed and avarice that are hurting so many and helping so few, today.

I don't intend to appear overly cynical as I do believe the large majority of people will treat others fairly if treated fairly in return, however the minute a Daniel Plainview or Eli Sunday attempt to take more for themselves through less scrupulous means "Henry Plainviews" start showing up everywhere looking to be excused, with the rest of society, from chastisement, for attempting the same.

This dynamic, and the ensuing result up to now, is beautifully explored by Paul Thomas Anderson, utilizing the extremely apt setting of the oil boom and evangelical movement to examine the type of Raskolnikov like figure or Nietzchean ubermensch (and their relationships with others) who find it so easy to flourish amid these two distinct, yet totally conducive, backdrops.

Daniel Day-Lewis delivers a once in a decade performance as Daniel Plainview, the monomaniacal chaser of oil who appears to see all humans, including his adopted son H.W., as a tool in his neverending pursuit of the unachieveable.

Plainview's relationship with his "son" probably provides the worst indictment of his true nature, but it is the cat and mouse like exchanges with preacher Eli Sunday throughout this film that best illustrates what those infected with the sickness of greed are willing to compromise to satisfy the craving.

Being that I find the manipulative nature of modern religion beyond infuriating I actually found myself somehow sympathetic to Plainview in those scenes where he is attempting to expose Eli, if only to Eli himself, for what Eli really is. (Google: "Joel Osteen money in walls" or "Catholic Church given $1.4 billion in covid PPP loans")

We then get to view Plainview from the reverse angle when his brother arrives, as Daniel was now subjected to the same manipulation of his innate desires he himself had become so proficient at uncovering and putting to work (probably even unconsciously in most cases) for himself, in others.

It is hard for me to describe the contempt with which I regard virtually all of the works of Paul Thomas Anderson, except to say that my resentment may be likened to that of a swindled mark, realizing only too late that he's been taken by a con man. "There Will Be Blood" establishes Anderson as a specialist in florid but ultimately vapid cinematic pseudo-poetry; a conceited artist who crafts intense characters, stark surroundings, and a persistently heightened emotional undercurrent completely incongruent with his impoverished material. Incongruent because the treasure chest he so ostentatiously bedecks contains nothing but air. In Anderson's world, style ever serves as a presumptuous stand-in for substance. Carefully embellished meaninglessness assumes the guise of a profound, impenetrable enigma. Memorable as they are, his characters never evolve, his plots never take full shape, and this particular film sprawls inertly across its ambitious running time exhibiting no hint of purpose or structural discipline. To be fooled by Anderson's work is to realize all too painfully one's own gullibility. To disdain his work is to attain the sober self-assurance that one will never again be duped by so transparent a charlatan.

In the course of his success and wealth, the wayward Plainview meets people who stand in his way. Even those in his inner circle.

Daniel Plainview is a complex character who, on paper, is just a bitter and ruthless man who doesn't like people and won't let anything or anyone stop him in his lust for power and money. Daniel Day-Lewis gives this unsympathetic character many more facets with his incredibly passionate performance. Initially a visibly passionate oil seeker and caring father, he develops into a greedy and loveless monster who additionally cultivates murderous intentions. That results from the highly sensitive soul Plainview carries within him. Day-Lewis is known for disappearing into his characters and never leaving them over the course of the entire film shoot. Nowhere does this ability come through more clearly and brilliantly than in There Will Be Blood. He manages to demonstrate an unexpectedly multi-dimensional character and make him somehow likeable despite all his misdeeds. This fact also underlies Paul Dano's portrayal of the priest Eli, whose chemistry with Day-Lewis' character could not be more toxic. Their scenes together are mostly pure madness and completely captivate you thanks to their terrific explosiveness. The performances of the two are clearly the focus of this film, which makes the other, mainly male actors, look like statits.

The point of the clear preponderance of male characters is a minor criticism. Plainview, for example, has no real interaction with a woman in the full 2 ½ hours, which is a concern given his epic screen time. Furthermore, the final act of the film must be viewed with a question mark, because it ends somewhat abruptly and exaggeratedly. As significant as the plot around the greed of capitalists, the importance of family and its religious component may be, it also gets lost in its tediousness at times. Without Day-Lewis' enormous presence, There Will Be Blood would not be the classic it is. Because of that, it has more than earned this status. But not only the phenomenal performances, but also a very close camera work and a score that always takes on a contrary mood to the action are among the film's great strengths. Even though the film is extremely quiet for over 80% and not very dialogue-heavy, these sequences with the beautiful images are hardly boring. When dialogue does occur, it is well written and perfectly delivered by the actors. There Will Be Blood is not a flawless film, but a memorable one.

The title of Paul Thomas Anderson's 2007 powerful period epic is a promise to the audience. It is eerie and intriguing. During the film's opening title card, the font is aged and gothic, immediately invoking a sense of antiquation. In fact, our tale begins in the waning years of the 19th century. The opening shot fades in—a bright New Mexican desert backdropped by Jonny Greenwood's swelling and unnerving string music, immediately attacking the viewer's senses like a buzzing swarm of locusts, reminiscent of Bernard Herrmann's score during the opening credits of "Psycho," the definitive sound of horror music. Anderson says, "Underneath it all, we were making a horror film."

We see a solitary man painstakingly prospecting for silver in a stony pit mine. After dynamiting a lode, he falls down the shaft and brutally breaks his leg. However, he is able to save a sample of silver before hauling himself back up. He is surrounded by mountains and rocks—an arid wasteland. We do not actually see his journey back to town, the viewer is forced to imagine him dragging himself by his elbows for miles and miles through the rugged terrain and suffocating heat to seek medical attention and more importantly, an assay office to certify his findings.

We have not yet learned his name or heard his voice, but this subtle moment tells the audience absolutely everything they need to know about the ruthless and relentless Daniel Plainview long before his salespitching, struggling to buy land, negotiating contracts, or establishing a reputation as an oil tycoon. Daniel accomplishing this improbable feat gives him the heroic right to every action that follows, even the unpleasant and despicable ones. He is not a bloodsucking businessman, like H.M. Tilford, whom Daniel tells to "scratch around in the dirt and find it like the rest of us instead of buying up someone else's hard work." Daniel himself is marred by sweat, blood, and oil.

Anderson adds, "It's hard for me not to see Plainview as a little bit heroic—he's enormously ambitious, and I can sympathize with his quest for survival, particularly during that time in the West." Throughout the film's first 20 minutes, we see the harsh conditions that paved the path to prosperity for Daniel Plainview and many other men during the early 20th century. Extracting oil from the ground is dangerous work as men perish along the way. When Daniel first strikes oil, he swipes his hand across the drill bit and raises it high above his head, a moment of triumph and discovery for our hero.

At the heart of the film is a conflict between two men, oil entrepreneur Daniel Plainview and young preacher Eli Sunday whose family's ranch sits atop oceans of oil which Plainview eventually reaps for massive profit. Two forces clash against one another—religion and capitalism, and neither one is portrayed in a favorable light. At the time of their meeting, Daniel and Eli share a lust for power and conquest. They are both rather nascent and interested in spreading their influence—Eli by proselytizing, and Daniel, by deed.

These two characters are set apart since Eli is a whiny baby-faced boy and Daniel is a man grown with a gruff voice similar to John Huston's. This voice provides the backbone for the character. Daniel's dulcet tones are paradoxically charming and perverse. For Eli and the followers of his church, the promised land is an intangible concept achieved by a lifetime of devotion to God. For Plainview and his associates, the promised land is beneath their very feet. It is through initiative and action they can bask in its glory. The film is best summed up by its tagline, "When ambition meets faith."

Oil was the lifeblood of industrialization and prosperity in America. "There Will Be Blood" does not mess around with metaphor or allegory, it is pure text for the beginning of capitalism in the Industrial Age and a re-enactment of historical events, e.g., Southern California's oil boom and the "robber baron" era of American industry. The film is a foretelling of the horrors of capitalism unchecked by morality, a theme which Anderson no doubt derived from the Upton Sinclair novel "Oil!" which "There Will Be Blood" is loosely based upon.

The American Dream is the foundation of many modern American values, such as faith in the idea that, through unceasing strife, one can renounce the circumstances of their birth and create a prosperous future for themselves. Plainview is a personification of this concept which would later be coined as "rugged individualism." As Jean-Paul Sartre put it, "Hell is other people." Daniel confesses to having "a competition" in him, wanting "no one else to succeed," and hating "most people." Men like him are most willing to manipulate and squash those around them, and therefore are rewarded the most. This, accompanied by his dreams of avarice, makes Daniel a living realization of American individualism, a genuine champion of capitalism, and a dark personification of the American dream. The film and its themes are dense, uncompromising and deeply American.

Upon an alternate viewing of the film, these aforementioned themes quickly fall to the wayside in favor of family emerging as the most important force in the film. The themes of greed and capitalism can easily be considered context for an emotional character study to unravel. Success and grandeur are meaningless without the bond of family to suppress the wistful longings of a troubled man. Plainview eventually becomes a reclusive alcoholic despite his massive wealth and large mansion. His tragic character arc resembles that of Charles Foster Kane. Just as Mr. Bernstein says, "It's no trick to make a lot of money… if all you want is to make a lot of money."

Daniel ends up with no family or real friends, just those who work for him. Unlike Kane, he lacks a "Rosebud," some nostalgic token he clings to or a redeeming quality he displays. Daniel feels no regret or pity, which drives him to unimaginable acts of madness and sociopathy.

The film is an extraordinary masterpiece, from a towering performance by virtuoso Daniel Day-Lewis, a brilliant cinematic set piece—the cataclysmic gas blowout and subsequent extinguishing of the oil fire, Jonny Greenwood's atonal score, and a brutal denouement full of sound and fury—all among the greatest in the history of modern cinema. "There Will Be Blood" is a wonderful portrait of a man consumed by ego and misanthropic contempt for anyone who steps in his path.

He attempts to evoke Citizen Kane (1941) and create his own masterpiece but he forgets that while that film was vast in scope and technically ambitious it also featured a compelling and sympathetic main character. Even as Kane descended into madness and abused those around him he retained a sense of childlike innocence and sweeping ambition that was crushed by his own trauma and loss of happiness as a child. We know little about Plainview as a child and when his brother shows up he seems to know little about him and his discussions with him fail to reveal much about him as a person. He is emotionally cold but he has been this way since the beginning of the film and so his abandonment of his son and brutal murder of those who have lied to him do not have the resonance that they should. His shocking brutality and lack of care about anything is exciting at first as we are not used to figures this unlikable but we quickly become bored of him as he does not change or grow in any way. This is a common problem with Anderson's films as he seems to identify with rigid men obsessed with their own greatness more than the fascinating characters he crafts on the fringe of the sprawling stories he writes.

The film blew me away in almost every way possible. The cinematography is absolutely stunning, especially the shots of the major gas blowout. But basically every shot in the film is beautiful. Amazing. Two days in a row, and two days of incredible movies that portray humans at their most raw. Still afflicted with Oscar fever, I followed up my viewing of The Reader with There Will Be Blood, which won Daniel Day-Lewis an Oscar for Best Actor last year.

Gritty, cold and, at times, cruel, this period piece set in the late 1800s through the Great Depression, There Will Be Blood is, at its core, about the business of...well, business, versus the business of salvation. Neither are proven to be better, or worse, as the case may be, than the other except for maybe, in the end, Daniel Day-Lewis' character is shown to be more exact in his evil, while his moral counterpart, Eli, is shown to be naive in his selfishness.

Paul Thomas Anderson continues his track record of unique and heavily character-driven films, in the vein of Boogie Nights, Magnolia and Punch-Drunk Love. As usual, his characters are immensely flawed and capable of the most atrocious of actions. He's quickly becoming a master of creating characters who actually do what only our darkest moments think of doing, if then.

As usual, Daniel Day-Lewis is outstanding in his role, commanding immense strength on the screen. The Oscar was well-deserved.

My only real criticism of the film is that the portrayal of Eli's religious con-man being made into the weak, whiny hypocrite that he becomes, comes across more as a personal indictment of Anderson's rather than an necessary element of the movie, specifically Eli's senseless murder in the end. Unlike the seemingly objectivity of The Reader, There Will Be Blood shamelessly overexaggerates the stupidity of the congregation (and, believe me, I cannot believe I'm saying that since I generally believe Christianity to be silly). If Eli is proven to be a great fool, what then of the congregation who put such faith in him? It rubbed me the wrong way, but didn't make me enjoy the film less. Perhaps portraying Daniel as an empty, soul-less man is meant to counter the naivete of his enemy.

Director Paul Thomas Anderson crafts a harrowing tale of an oil baron building his life. It is massive in scope, but never forgets its heart. You get to watch a man manipulate, con, and steamroll his way to success. It is a character study of Daniel Plainview as much as it is an epic on the rise of capitalism. You bear witness to a father attempting to raise a boy, while prioritizing his business. There Will Be Blood is truly a monster. It's lengthy run time feels quite slow as I suspect most viewers will find its molasses pace to be too crawling. I assure you however, the pay off is well worth the wait. It is a brilliant story told in an incredible way.

Paul Thomas Anderson finds every interesting angle to showcase the acting performances, bleak environment, and dismal prospects. You will be astonished by There Will Be Blood's sights. I think the narrative alone is worth the price of admission. Anderson delivers a compelling tale based on Upton Sinclair's "Oil!" 

Although, Anderson could edit down his films more, he gives you everything. The elongated shots, one takes, panning shots, and clever sequences all work to keep you enthralled to the madness on screen.

As I mentioned, the acting is top tier in There Will Be Blood. Daniel Day-Lewis and Paul Dano play the most cruel, manipulative, self-absorbed monsters in cinema history. They portray men that care not for others and they play it beautifully. All their subtle movements and eye work reveal their deeper convictions. These are what powerhouse performances look like.

Musically, this movie lavishes itself in deep pondering silence. It is broken up by rushing themes that spark the imagination as to the sounds of industrialization. The score to There Will Be Blood is equally gripping and terrifying. The pounding sounds herein mirror the march of progress. From the slow thudding pulses of noise to the hectic insanity of big business. Composer Jonny Greenwood delivers a wholly original composition for you. I found it flows over you to push you into the air like one of Plainview's oil geysers.

I recommend There Will Be Blood for anyone that can stand weighty movies in run time and themes. There is a great story here if only Anderson had cut it down some. I still enjoyed the film and found it fascinating all the while. Give it a chance if you can stomach the blood promised in the title.

Strengths: Any conversation about this film must start with Daniel Day-Lewis. He plays the lead, Daniel Plainview, and gives one of the best performances of his entire career. When you think about how storied his time as an actor has been, you understand what that kind of praise means. He completely becomes Plainview to the point where you almost forget he's acting. He totally lacks empathy and or any kind of likable qualities, yet the performance is so good, he works as a protagonist. Paul Thomas Anderson does a wonderful job showcasing capitalism in this era and crafting an intense feature film. The cinematography is top notch. There's also some strong performances outside of DDL that people may overlook. Paul Dano (Paul and Eli Sunday) pulls double duty and handles both roles with care, while Kevin J. O'Connor (Henry) is strong as Plainview's supposed half-brother.

Weaknesses: One thing that usually makes a film work is a character arc. We want to go on a journey with our character where they grow from start to finish. Plainview gets more wealthy and greedy as time goes on, but doesn't ever seem to learn anything. He drives everyone away, including his son. The film ends on a weird note. Daniel murders Eli in his bowling alley, clearly a wealthy man now, and that's it. It doesn't feel like a complete film, despite running at a very long 158 minutes. 

Overall: It's widely considered to be some sort of masterpiece, but I just didn't see that. It's very good. It just seems to lack the kind of character development that classics should have. Plainview seems to have one motivation and that's it. The ending is also weak. However, it's a must-see movie purely for Daniel Day-Lewis. He is scary good in this role and it needs to be experienced.

In art and in life, I am always running from Daniel, the definitive peak of decadence that you never want to reach, as an artist who strives to inspire people for the betterment of humanity, and as a human being who must always love people more than life experience. Ordinarily there are two types of movies that are extremely easy to talk about: ones I love, and ones I hate. Usually it's only the middling movies where I struggle to have the passion to articulate much about the experience. Well, There Will Be Blood is a film that I absolutely loved and by all rights I should be overflowing with words to describe why, yet I'm having trouble pinpointing what it was that made me so passionate about it. I think it's pretty obvious that one thing that makes it special is the stunning performance from Daniel Day-Lewis. There's so much depth to the character of Daniel Plainview that I never knew what to expect next. It felt like at any moment he could reach across a table and stab the person he's talking to in the neck, or just as easily embrace them with an insincere hug. The plot of the film perfectly shows how passion and determination shaped this character, and how he could either have great success or great failure because of his pride. At first I was put off by Paul Dano in the role of the young pastor who makes Daniel's life more difficult. But, as the film progressed, I saw how his baby-face and grating personality would be perfect for someone who stands in Daniel's way.

So many of the moments in There Will Be Blood are the kind of things that I would ordinarily hate. It is slow-moving and long, the plot is not unique or complex, and most of the characters are completely unlikable. Yet I was absolutely mesmerized by this film. The cinematography was perfect, the music set a great tone, the dialogue was sparse but always meaningful, and so much was going on in the characters' heads even when no words were spoken. The ending might be one of the most intense and unexpected ways to conclude a film that I can imagine. Even though I have heard certain lines of dialogue from that scene before, I didn't realize the context and they mean nothing until you hear them delivered by Daniel Day-Lewis. When it was done all I wanted was to know what happened next. They left me wanting more, and yet also resolved everything that the film had been building towards. I think all movie fans should give There Will Be Blood a chance. It is a movie that resonated with me in ways I never would have expected, and in my opinion it probably should have won against The Departed for Best Picture.

Paul Thomas Anderson's There Will Be Blood is an intense drama focused on the conflict between ruthless capitalist Daniel Plainview (Daniel Day-Lewis) and egotistical preacher Eli Sunday (Paul Dano). On the surface the film is about an early 20th century oil prospector building his wealth in Southern California. However the film's themes and subplots go far deeper, exposing a highly complex story about family, business, religion and human nature. It is a thought provoking masterpiece of filmmaking that stayed with me after the end credits and seemed to improve the more I considered and reflected on it.

The most striking and obvious talking point of the film is Daniel Day-Lewis' performance, which rightfully won him an Oscar. His manages to shift from terrifyingly intense to unnervingly quiet from scene to scene. Day-Lewis brings the most out of Anderson's writing with expert delivery packed with emotion. He also brings an incredible physical element to the role in the subtle ways he demonstrates power with his walk, the way he holds himself in scenes and his piercing, ever present gaze. He effortlessly coveys the character's ruthlessness and detachment from others, and adds a feeling of tension whenever he's on screen. However Paul Dano is by no means overshadowed as he delivers a powerhouse performance as Eli Sunday and his brother Paul. Like Day-Lewis he can shift from almost maniacal preaching to calmness resulting in a similar unnerving feeling. It is a shock that he was not even nominated for best supporting actor at the 2008 Oscars as it really is effortlessly brilliant. It is also worth noting Dillon Freasier as Daniel Plainview's son, HW. Despite his young age he gives a talented well-rounded performance that results in a convincing and hugely important father son relationship.

The real star of the film however is Jonny Greenwood's score. It is continuously ominous and foreboding, giving every scene an air of threat. It almost feels like a score for a horror film which, combined with the tense performances and complex writing, gives the film an element of real life terror. The power of the score means that even when it isn't in a scene you still have the intensity due to the way it builds up, making the silences feel like everything is coming to a head. The climactic scene removes the background music, allowing Day-Lewis and Dano to really hit home. Combining this score with Robert Elswit's beautiful cinematography really drives home the brilliance of this film. Elswit uses reasonably lengthy takes to capture the performances, and epic wide shots to capture the astonishing scenery. The film's big action moment, where oil shoots out of the ground to create a towering inferno, is a work of cinematic art.

Overall There Will Be Blood boasts everything needed to create the perfect film. Incredible writing, complex characters, award winning performances, an astounding score and expert cinematography. It delivers a realistic, yet often terrifying, story that will make you think. A true masterpiece.

Now we throw perhaps the greatest actor of the generation, Daniel Day Lewis, into the mix and we take a rather basic and boring concept and turn it into something exciting and downright incredible.  Paul Thomas Anderson takes the helm for There Will Be Blood and Johnny Greenwood (radiohead) takes control of the eery off tune music for the movie.  We are thrust into the world of Daniel Plainview (played by Daniel Day Lewis) and his rise to power in the oil industry.  It is a brutal rise to the top for this character.  He is ruthless, cutthroat and downright barbaric on his way to getting what he wants.  Played to perfection by Day Lewis who earned his second of three Oscars for acting for this movie.  The characters entire persona can be summed up by one quote he utters while in deep thought " I hate most people"  Paul Dano gives a very good performance as a young priest in a tiny village where Plainview is drilling for oil.  But as we soon find out through the movie everyone is not as pure as they seem.  As ruthless as Plainview is in this movie, at least he is up front about it and does not hide his greed.  Daniel Day Lewis gives the best performance of his career so far which is saying something, because he always seems to give the best performance of his career in every movie he does.  I cannot leave this review without mentioning the great cinematography and music throughout the entire film.  Amazingly visual movie.  And Johnny Greenwood does a fantastic job with the music creating a very disturbing eery feel for the entire movie.

Considering that I first saw this when I was about 13 and hadn't revisited it since, I decided it was time to return to 'There Will Be Blood' - a film that I remember liking, but never understanding the astonishingly high praise. Ultimately, I think I was a little too young to fully appreciate what this film is really about; and how truly magnificent it really is.

There's far too much to cover in one review, so here's something I thought about when the film was over. The first thing I noticed this time around that I was definitely too young to appreciate before was the religious debate that runs throughout the entire film, represented by Daniel and Eli. On a character level, the two are both surprisingly similar, in the sense that they are both controlling and both want the same thing - power and recognition - and naturally that causes a rift to form between them. But I also noticed that, along with Daniel's descent into madness comes his rejection of religion; which is for all intents and purposes represented in Eli. From the very first scene, in which Daniel must crawl and shuffle his way back to civilisation over rocks and mountains, it's clear that this is a man who has not been afforded much luck. Any fortune he's had has been gained through struggle and perseverance against the odds. And, as is the same with all people - including myself - poor fortune and unluckiness tend to make one more and more bitter. So when H.W. loses his hearing and all control is taken away from him, any small hope of a bright future is lost, and Daniel loses any and all optimism that he had left. From then on, he is concerned for himself and himself only. As far as he is concerned, God doesn't exist - and if he does, he's not worth following. This build up of hatred and disillusionment over his life culminates in the final scenes with Eli, where he finally condemns any kind of higher power for good.

As stated, that was just one of the things going through my head after this film ended. That could all be rubbish, but there are so many rabbit holes to explore that I would need to watch the film a hundred times to fully understand it. Part of the reason it works so well is that we can all identify with Daniel in some way or another. Most of what I've just said likely says more about me than anyone else, but then that's what I want out of a film. Masterfully crafted as usual by P.T.A., this marks a turning point in his career as a filmmaker. I love his earlier work (with 'Magnolia' one of my absolute favourites), and I love 'There Will Be Blood', but in a different way. Anderson has stated that there's nothing worse than a filmmaker who won't act their age - who won't grow up. Whilst his earlier films were playful and ultimately more accessibly entertaining, he has matured and developed with this film; which is far more thoughtful and complex than anything he made before it, and possibly anything that will come after.

Paul Thomas Anderson's adaptation of Upton Sinclair's "Oil!" is so very good it is challenging for me to fully express how good it really it. First of all, this is not really an "adaptation" of Sinclair's work. "Oil!" only serves as a sort of "springing board" into the story that Anderson tells. Staring Daniel Day-Lewis and Paul Dano the film follows the story of Day-Lewis' "Daniel Plainview" who is first presented as determined silver-minor with a burning ambition to be an "Oil Man.' Determination quickly morphs into ruthless. His only "grounding" arrives in the form of a son who's own father is killed a tragic accident. Plainview's first real threat comes in the form of power-hungry young preacher. 

At it's core the film is about the rage-filled greed of two men. The question is, which of these two men has the most rage to win what becomes an epic battle. In other words, the creation of Corporate America. 

The two leading actors are brilliant, but PT Anderson is actually the star here. Even with a long running time, "There Will Be Blood" moves at a fast pace. 2 hours and 38 minutes feels like under 90 minutes under Anderson's watch. The movie is actually a grim satire which is largely concerned as being an homage to Stanley Kubrick. From the first shot and sound, Kubrick is the clear muse here. From the beginning to the unforgettable ending in which Mr. Plainview seems to not only be living in the Outlook Hotel but he appears to even be wearing Jack's sweater. There are no ghosts or surrealism here -- the demon that haunts our protagonist is greed. Brilliant.

It is an exploration of our own embedded weaknesses and the reality of our personalities. It reeks of characteristic displeasure, and abuses the viewer for our impulse to relate and accept the protagonist at first whim. It is a discouraging and utterly liberating effort from Paul Thomas Anderson, a director whose capabilities often transcend those of his competitors by miles. His status as one of this generation's most exemplary and consistent filmmakers rivals that of the esteem that is held for directors and screenwriters of the likes of Golden Age directors that include Stanley Kubrick, Alfred Hitchcock and Orson Welles. Both cinephiles and general moviegoers consistently provide acclaim for his dense, intelligent character-studies; films that whilst always providing variety between not only the general cinematic output but Anderson's own pictures, always come back to a multitude of recurring themes, ideas and disparities. These include namely love lost and perhaps even found; the desire for a family; the inner-corruption that exists within any given person, no matter how chivalrous or kindly they may seem on the perceptible exterior, and alcoholism/drug abuse or general indulgence in excess. The latter is generally the most prominent and easily discerned, but the others are always evident with but a smidge of analyzation, though this isn't to discredit the intelligence and sentimental force of his works. That is just to say that their themes can be distinguished, examined and appreciated by nearly all. Considering There Will Be Blood features all these components with great wealth, I've figured it would be best to examine each individual concept within There Will Be Blood that I've listed above.

Love: Lost and Found

The protagonist of the picture, Daniel Plainview, like many of Anderson's lead characters, is a man conflicted in terms of how he deals with other people and holds relationships with them. His most obvious comparison from another P.T.A picture is Lancaster Dodd within The Master, who features an inability to remain loyal to his supposed friends, or build relationships easily. He is distant to many, and remains inconceivable to many of the strange, weird and discontent personalities he meets along his road. This is until he discovers Freddie Quell, a fellow soul who seeks someone who can accurately understand him. Dodd is cautious, and remains distant to many. Freddie is someone whom he not only feels one with, but can understand on a subconscious level as well. Dodd can manipulate him and play him, but he can also derive pleasure from their talks and discussions. Plainview seeks to manipulate those around him, and his shields are up constantly. He is hesitant to let anyone in without fully analysing their being prior, and as his descent into madness and excessive vigilance continues, he becomes elusive to people around him. Even from the onset of the picture, within the first two scenes, he seems completely separate from everyone. But he finds a soul in need; a child who requires caring, and he undertakes the job of raising it. But it's not that he necessarily has an underlying paternal instinct, but more so that he seeks someone who can be wholly his. H.W, this adopted son of Daniel's, grows up under the authority of his non-biological father, and is manipulated into becoming a shadow of Daniel's own personality and desires. Daniel, a man who wishes to control any situation or any individual, finds the perfect creature to tame and teach; a creature which doesn't yet have any idea of what is right or wrong.

But as H.W is subjected to a terrible accident that leaves him incapable of hearing, his innocence and single-minded faith in his supposed "father" starts to deteriorate. He begins to become aware of the terrifying manipulations of the man he has loved for so very long, and wishes to undermine him in a number of ways. The ultimate spite being that by the end of the film he wishes to leave his father and become an oil miner of his own accord; in practice, become Daniel's own competitor. It is here, when Daniel realises he can no longer manipulate this boy who he has treasured, cared for and shaped for so many years, that he disowns H.W and denounces him as a bastard. It's heartbreaking to witness the inevitable destruction of this relationship, one which brews for many years, but must, as is due to the volatile nature of Daniel's character, come to an end. No matter who Plainview lets in, he is either betrayed, becomes paranoid or is either plain blunt in his distaste for that individual that their relationship is condemned. Either that, or we don't (alongside Daniel) get to truly become close to that character; Ciarian Hinds' Fletcher is a good example of such. As such, Daniel Plainview is resigned throughout the entire picture to exhibiting little love; his inability to maintain courteous throughout any of his relationships with any of the main supporting ensemble of characters proves his reluctance to provoke human connection.

The Desire For a Family

This thematic concept is obvious (or is it?). Plainview, throughout the entire film desires a family of some sort. Or perhaps this isn't, in fact, the case; the metaphor is in-and-of itself a metaphor for Daniel desiring a place he can simply fit in. This doesn't necessarily mean he's looking for people who he can belong to, but just a place he feels content within. Although for Daniel, this seems like an impossible yearning, for he never seems fully satisfied with any one location throughout nearly the entire duration of the picture. His arrival at Little Boston is full of excitement, and dreams of a prosperous future, but he enrages people, spites some of the figureheads of the community, and is not willing to provide simple decency in a number of cases. This is not his home, nor will it be his end. Where he ends up at the end of the picture, in a massive mansion, fit with luxuries many fantasize about owning; he is not even appeased with this, and this location perfectly fits his aspiration for someplace to "get away to"; something that he states within one of his conversations with the fake Henry Brands.

Maybe it's the journey that Plainview enjoys most. When he has found a resolution he becomes impatient. He wants a challenge or a feat that requires conquering. Oil is a never-ending, fruitful bearer of prosperity that continues to give and take even to this day. It is not as consistent as, say, farming wheat, and it provides competition for all those involved. It is a relentless and compelling practice that maintains Daniel's will to live, for without the consistent drive (as we bear witness to at the end), his life becomes a shamble. By the finale of the picture, his descent to darkness, and his discontent attitude; his lack of love, family, proper home, mean that he is little more than a shadow of his former being. The confident businessmen we come across in the beginning of the picture dissolves, his inability to form connection and lay his possessions in a single place proving detrimental to his eventual state.

Again, this character can be connected to one of The Master, this time Freddie Quell. He travels abound, his life confused and without real purpose, or so we believe; when the film draws closer to its final act, it is revealed Freddie feels unsatisfied by his path in life, and he diverts from the road that Dodd is setting him upon. He feels liberated once again, and we come to a realisation. Quell will never be satisfied by the kill, but only the hunt. The emotional barrage he had endured within World War II destroyed his capability to draw proper, natural human connection. He is a lost soul in need, swimming amongst the abyss of his own self, unable to find any other to stick with. Plainview is much the same, as despite his attempts to settle down or succumb to the desire to find and remain with a home or family, his own personality dictates that he is unable to achieve such. He will be eternally unhappy with himself and his position, and he must desire for something greater at all stages. He is a man who has defied all forms of relative success, and he needs something extreme to find the pleasure of happiness; the murder of Eli is a prime example.

Inner-Corruption

Even from the beginning of the film, where the false facade that Plainview projects onto his targets is at its height, there is something that is strangely unnerving about our protagonist that forces us to look at him with scrutiny at the forefront of our perception. Whilst he seems well-tempered at first, his moments of weakness and the various secrets that shroud his character all throughout the picture force us to remain attentive in regards to his actions, and impose perusal on his every move. When Plainview begins to unravel and his moral ambiguity shifts to the foreground of the viewer's attention, this inner-corruption that seemed inevitable from the beginning begins to seep forth. From the second that Eli and Plainview meet each other, it is clear to us that their conflicting personalities and world views (one of them a clear defender of industrialism and the other a stern opposition) will lead to a form of confrontation that may very well define the individuals. Both of them, unrelenting believers in their separate viewpoints, eventually force each other to experience a catharsis of some sort, and unveil the evil and destruction in each other. Eli forces Daniel to submit to the knowledge that he did abandon his son, and that he is a sinner; Daniel admits his treachery and seems to almost become more content with his acts.

On the other end of the spectrum, Daniel challenges Eli and his beliefs, and deduces that the latter man is a sinner of a bad nature and heart. Despite his attempts to be a man of God, he is capable of succumbing, like any other, to the temptations that humans and men are prone to. These two supposedly incorruptible human beings; a man who initially seems overtly formal and of a tender heart, and a young man of God who preaches about redemption and higher reward which awaits the good in the afterlife; both of them fall prey to the allure of women, illicit substances, alcohol, criminal activity, etc. Underneath the polished and refined shell there is a dark and defining personality that is brought out by these two corrupted, evil, detestable human beings interacting with each other.

In some ways, of all the people in the picture, Eli is Daniel's soul-mate; a man of an equally ambitious, single-minded pursuit whose preliminary appearance reflects little on his eventual outcome.

Indulgence

The slow deterioration in Plainview is represented throughout with the quantity of alcohol consumed. As he begins to drink more and more, his professionalism, pride and formality drifts away to reveal the blunt man inside who isn't willing to discount his own personal beliefs for those of any others. This is comparable to Freddie Quell, Doc Sportello, or Dirk Diggler, from The Master, Inherent Vice and Boogie Nights respectively, all individuals who suffered from indulgence in terms of felonious materials and alcoholic beverages, some for positive effect, others less so. Doc's effected state throughout much of Inherent Vice provides a great quantity of the laughs and fun throughout; Freddie and Dirk's conditions lead to their individual imminent demises, Dirk in particular being affected so much that paranoia begins to infect his every move, and he becomes a hollow shell of his former being. Plainview's drinking issue forms him into a recluse, angry at the world for reasons that aren't wholly decipherable. That said, it is clear that he is angry at certain human beings, his physical decline, his place in life and his lack of a partner. He is lonely. His drinking turns him into a solitary figure, an aimless shell of his former self, and so in the circle of life (or the antonym for such), he continues to indulge in his liquor. He is a hopeless being, rich enough in wealth to continue his habits, but poor enough in resolve to stop them. It is an inevitable, tragic tale of misery, from the moment we see the underlying rage that Plainview possesses within himself.

Other Comments

Anderson tells this calamitous story of unavoidable collapse with ease, drifting amongst both tales and dialogues of immense metaphysical weight and pairing them beside general discussion, all of it fluid and seemingly simplistic, the transitions in mood, tone and character arc always subtle. Anderson foreshadows the defeat of his protagonist with scenes featuring great tensity, where Plainview is unable to suppress his irritability with people of an assumed lesser intellect, and gradually builds the importance of these moments to a point in time where it is undeniable that Plainview is slipping into the depths of anger and despair. The story is always paced cleanly; what would be considered the most major of events are given the same kind of significance as something far less blatantly large; a discussion around a table where there is a certain amount of disparity and tension between the individuals partaking is provided with the same amount of screen time as a murder at the hands of our lead character. And where as this could backfire in the face of any amateur director, Anderson effortlessly weaves the nugatory into the consequential, forming a consistently engaging palette of imagery and conversations.

The imagery in and of itself is typically incredible, though as understated as I've ever witnessed Anderson, his usual visual flair, as depicted in Boogie Nights and The Master most obviously, far less prominent than one would anticipate. In fact, in much the way that David Fincher utilizes POV angles, Anderson seems to almost try and hide his bigger moments of spectacle. Long and arduous takes which last minutes of length (and these aren't a one-time kind of thing; Anderson constantly utilizes this kind of a shot all throughout) flow effortlessly from (generally) behind a character, before following them into a new location or towards a new character or entity. Entire conversations are shot in this way, and it's stunningly executed, but Anderson always seems to be underplaying the significance of these moments. He doesn't want to distract the average viewer from the spectacle of the story or characters, and so cinematographer Robert Elswit's work is both more difficult, and less noticeable (by the way, this understated intention is being applauded by me).

There Will Be Blood finds issue namely in its score, composed by Jonny Greenwood, and some of its backlighting, which proves distracting and unnecessary. Greenwood's score is a dull assortment of loud, obtrusive, aggressive and overpowering rhythms and melodies, only some of it actually accenting themes, motifs and character intentions that are occurring on screen or are being foreshadowed. It's a disappointing effort, though I can fortunately report that Greenwood's collaborations with Anderson vastly increase in compositional prowess, emotive range and thematic density within The Master and Inherent Vice; namely the latter. All the same, this work is no where near the level required for such an explosive, riveting and emblematic picture.

All the same, it's hard to deny that There Will Be Blood is an absolutely astounding picture, and one that proves justly compelling for its two hour length. The characters depicted are engrossing enough that I would've been happy to have viewed them for another hour, their plights and declines utterly impeccable. Anderson is of the likes of Fincher; a director who possesses the rare ability to be able to hold an audience member's attention for upwards of two hours with glorious performances, a centred and captivating screenplay, brilliant sound design which brings us into the locations shown (though there was one diner scene where, much like this one from The Wolf of Wall Street, a lack of background sound can be fathomed), production design which further enunciates the realism of the time period portrayed, and cinematography that, in true Anderson fashion, transcends general work and manages to enhance the story dramatically and in terms of scale. This is another spectacle of great emotional power that entrances one and doesn't let go until the very end; one of Anderson's most important, brutal, delightful and harrowing confections to date, that exposes his true potential for extensive and sweeping character-based drama. There is certainly blood flowing within the veins of this rampant picture.

Paul Thomas Anderson's There Will Be Blood is a sweeping, grand masterpiece of modern cinema. It is a daring, brooding, glorious achievement. This is a film for those who love movies, those impressed by a daring shot, a tense dialogue exchange, beautiful imagery, and incredible acting. The movie doesn't have much of a difficult plot to follow. Daniel Plainview, an oilman, is prospecting for oil, and his greed makes him buy out all of the land around his wells for fear of drainage. He brings his son, H.W., adopted from an old, dead business partner, into the "family" business, run by lies and deceit. He buys a large area of land from the Sunday family and sets up his oil derricks, making incredible profits as a town builds up around them. Eli Sunday is a smart young man. He wants money from Daniel for his church, the church of the Third Revelation. A dangerous rivalry erupts between the two of them, and there will indeed be blood.

There Will Be Blood is not so much about plot as it is about acting, writing, and direction. It is a gorgeously composed film with haunting performances and it features one of the most highly quotable and greatest screenplays in recent memory. The acting in the film is absolutely incredible. The movie rests on the shoulders of Daniel Day-Lewis. He is in just about every scene, and his performance is crucial to the film's success. He is more than capable in the role. His Daniel Plainview is one of the very greatest pieces of acting I have ever seen. It is a towering performance. His gruff voice and exaggerated facial expressions, often of rage, along with his limp from a leg broken early in the film, help him craft a character that is fierce and memorable. His chin is covered in stubble, and a glorious mustache grows below his nose. He is a seedy, greedy, dangerous man, and cares about nothing more than his own success.

Opposite Daniel Plainview in the film is Eli Sunday, the preacher at the Church of the Third Revelation, and I realize more and more with every viewing of this film that he is basically just as corrupt and creepy as Daniel Plainview himself. Paul Dano's performance is fantastic, and he holds his own against Daniel Day-Lewis admirably, even if he does not quite reach his co-star's level.

There Will Be Blood is absolutely gorgeous to look at. Robert Elswit's beautiful cinematography creates images that stick in your head. He films breathtaking landscapes and striking close-ups with seeming ease. Behind the camera also is Paul Thomas Anderson, one of the best directors working today, a man with an encyclopedic knowledge of cinema and a natural eye for composition. His shots are wonderful to behold. They are often daring. Shots play out for extended amounts of time. Complex tracking shots are utilized for maximum effect. Anderson never takes the easy way out, and he crafts a glorious style and captivating pacing that would have been lost with a lesser filmmaker. He is also great with actors, which is obvious considering the performances he elicits from his cast in this film.

There Will Be Blood is a movie that is made up of one great scene after another. There are so many moments in the film that I adore that it would be almost tedious to recount them all; it would be best just to watch the movie yourself. This is a film that I cannot recommend highly enough. It is a breathtaking, thought-provoking, incredible cinematic experience.

I may not want to talk about every great moment in the film right now; however, there are four scenes in particular - my four favorite scenes in the film -that I would like to discuss.

The first of my favorite scenes in the film comes when an eruption of oil explodes into flames, turning Daniel Plainview's derrick into a fiery inferno. His boy is thrown to the ground by the force of the oil rushing toward the heavens, permanently deafened. Daniel cares but is far more interested in saving the oil. The simplistic, primal music. The sound drops out. The long shot of Daniel running with his son toward safety. The cutting of the ropes. The fire of the derrick at night. This haunting, harrowing sequence is among the most breathtaking and incredible in modern cinema history. It is also symbolic and important to the narrative, and in more ways than it just deafens H.W. Plainview. Daniel had refused to let Eli bless the derrick before drilling began. Soon after, a man died while working on it. Then, the derrick erupted into flames. Daniel may see religion as "one goddamn helluva show," but the movie, in this powerful, memorable scene, makes a statement of religion and faith being something more, and that to go against faith leads to damnation and fire and death.

There is a great scene later in the film in which Daniel, angry at Eli for not being able to use his holy "powers" to save H.W.'s hearing, and angry at him for his greed at wanting money for his church, slaps him across the face and throws him down into a lake of oil, covering both of them in the black gold, screaming at him in a fiery rage. "I'm going to bury you underground, Eli." He means it.

In order to obtain new tracts of land for his oil wells, Daniel is forced to be baptized into Eli's church. This baptism scene is one of the best scenes in the entire film. Earlier, Daniel had abandoned his child and killed a man who claimed to be his brother. Daniel is hung over and doesn't want to be baptized, but he lets Eli force him to scream out whatever it takes. Daniel has to say that he is sorry for the sins that he has committed, and he mumbles after Eli whatever Eli says. Then Eli makes him scream out that he abandoned his child. Daniel mumbles it at first, then looks at Eli in rage. Finally, he erupts, screaming at the top of his lungs, "I've abandoned my child! I've abandoned my child! I've abandoned my boy!" He then calms down, the holy water drenching the top of his head.

The ending of the film is abrupt and shocking. It brutally ends the struggle between Daniel and Eli. Daniel turns the tables on Eli and belittles him, making him cry to the heavens that he is a false prophet and that God is a superstition. Daniel then talks about drainage using a now-infamous metaphor: "If you have a milkshake and I have a milkshake and I have a straw and my straw reaches across the room and starts to drink your milkshake. I drink your milkshake! I drink it up!" The scene erupts into violence and the movie ends with a character's head becoming a pool of blood, fulfilling the promise of the title and ending the power struggle between these two greedy, corrupt men.

Other great scenes in the film include a lengthy rant between Daniel Plainview and his supposed brother about cynicism and Daniel's hatred of man, and how Daniel looks at most people and sees nothing worth liking. He wants nobody else to succeed. There is a great scene near the end of the film in which Daniel and H.W., returned to him at last, share a meal and some not so kind words with oil executives. The final scene between Daniel and H.W. is dark and haunting.

This is a powerful and intelligent film, highly symbolic and allegorical, that exposes the dangers of greed and ambition and the dark side of religion. The most iconic line from 2007-"I drink your milkshake!" Paul Thomas Anderson's amazing drama THERE WILL BE BLOOD (2007) does not have anything to do with milkshakes, but that is an amazing line from the movie (if you know the context). The film is inspired by the book Oil!, and tells the story of miner-turned-oilman Daniel Plainview (Daniel Day-Lewis) and his ruthless pursuit of wealth during the oil boom of the late 19th century and early 20th century. As you can probably guess, Daniel Day-Lewis won the Best Actor Oscar that year... Because he is Daniel Day-Lewis... And he is an acting god. But, I do have to praise both Paul Dano and Dillon Freasier (the latter of which plays the young H.W. Plainview) who gave astounding performances although acting alongside a legend.

I have not seen a lot of PTA's movies, but this was the first PTA film I had ever seen and I could immediately tell how fantastic of a film maker he is. Almost every single aspect of this film was close to perfect and though There Will Be Blood is kind of dependent on Day-Lewis' performance, it still has a great script, impressive music, powerful supporting performances, and breathtaking cinematography to back it up. Granted, the film probably would not work if someone else was playing Plainview, but who cares? Day-Lewis killed it and gave the best performance of his career in my opinion. If you do not know this already, Day-Lewis is the ULTIMATE method actor-he took an entire year to get prepared for this role, and he has done that with every movie he has done in the past. One negative that I have to directly point out though is that the film does not completely make use of its time period; There Will Be Blood could have definitely built upon other aspects of society at the time.

But Day-Lewis though..... WOW!!! Almost every time I watch a Daniel Day-Lewis movie, I feel enlightened in a way because that guy elevates every film he is in to the next tier and has the ability to transform something good or mediocre to something GREAT or MAGNIFICENT! He always becomes the character; I never see a shred of Daniel Day-Lewis in anything character he portrays. And as for Daniel Plainview, he is hands down one of the greatest and most malevolent villains of the 2000s, maybe even of all time. I would describe this person as the literal representation of evil-seriously, that is the perfect way to describe him. Every callous action this man took only further developed his immense greed and ambition. And as I was following the story, I saw that as he kept abandoning his morals and his loved ones, his evil persona kept growing and growing until it became a prodigious monster. Those final scenes between Plainview and an older H.W., and also Plainview and Eli were spectacular and showed the transformation Daniel Plainview had undergone! He is already so malicious at the beginning of the movie, yet he had become one hundred times more corrupt by the end. And of course, the "I drink your milkshake!" scene-that completed the ascension of Plainview from an insane, but intelligent, business man to a LEGENDARY VILLAIN.

But as great as he is, I have to bring attention towards Paul Dano who brilliantly played the twins, Paul and Eli Sunday. Dano was awesome in the film, and primarily appeared as Eli. The character is the head of the church in the town that Plainview tries to drill oil from and there are two important scenes in which he performs a sermon: one for an old lady, the other for Plainview himself. And, in essence... He blew me away. Simply that; Paul Dano gave his best and most memorable performance as the Sunday twins. Actually, I'm genuinely surprised the guy is not in more movies these days (he was in Prisoners though, and that was awesome). But I really want to see Dano in more films, he is such a talent and with a resume that has There Will Be Blood on it, he will surely have a long, worthwhile career. On the other hand, child actor Dillon Freasier was a revelation. He barely has any lines in the film, but he is still standout and held his own against Day-Lewis. Unfortunately, Freasier has not been in any other movies since and had passed on some other roles offered to him at the time, so I'm suspecting he will not go back into acting. That makes me sad because I truly thought there was a possibility to see him in more movies and to see him develop into a greater actor-he had a lot of potential.

Now the technical aspects of There Will Be Blood are astounding! This is actually the same for every PTA movie-they are all BEAUTIFUL FILMS! Roger Elswit's cinematography and Jonny Greenwood's phenomenal score are a large part of why the movie is so damn great. The film has a lot of scenes in which the majority of the scene is mainly one shot focused on a person's face (primarily Daniel). It never switches to different angles of that person or of the other people in the scene. Surprisingly, I was captivated the entire time though it was just one head filling the screen instead of a large variety of shots; I personally feel as if PTA was trying to make sure that in some of those scenes the film was contributing to Daniel's intention for all the attention being drawn towards him and staying with HIM. One of my favorite scenes in which Greenwood really has a chance to explicitly utilize his score and elevate the scene was the scene in which the oil at one of Plainview's wells had caught fire (again) and it sends everyone into a frenzy. If you've seen the movie, then you know how awesome the music of that scene is.

I keep having to come back to the milkshake scene though. I mean it when I say that was the most iconic line of 2007, probably the most iconic scene too. It is just so freaking unforgettable and it defined the film. Every time I have a milkshake now, I immediately think of Daniel Plainview, which is not necessarily great since he is such a cruel and wicked character. He is badass villain in general though. Everyone should go see There Will Be Blood. There is no point in watching the milkshake scene unless you know the context, right? Overall, it is an astounding movie nonetheless and is definitely worth watching - 9.7/10

Amazing. Two days in a row, and two days of incredible movies that portray humans at their most raw. Still afflicted with Oscar fever, I followed up my viewing of The Reader with There Will Be Blood, which won Daniel Day-Lewis an Oscar for Best Actor last year.

Gritty, cold and, at times, cruel, this period piece set in the late 1800s through the Great Depression, There Will Be Blood is, at its core, about the business of...well, business, versus the business of salvation. Neither are proven to be better, or worse, as the case may be, than the other except for maybe, in the end, Daniel Day-Lewis' character is shown to be more exact in his evil, while his moral counterpart, Eli, is shown to be naive in his selfishness.

Paul Thomas Anderson continues his track record of unique and heavily character-driven films, in the vein of Boogie Nights, Magnolia and Punch-Drunk Love. As usual, his characters are immensely flawed and capable of the most atrocious of actions. He's quickly becoming a master of creating characters who actually do what only our darkest moments think of doing, if then.

As usual, Daniel Day-Lewis is outstanding in his role, commanding immense strength on the screen. The Oscar was well-deserved.

My only real criticism of the film is that the portrayal of Eli's religious con-man being made into the weak, whiny hypocrite that he becomes, comes across more as a personal indictment of Anderson's rather than an necessary element of the movie, specifically Eli's senseless murder in the end. Unlike the seemingly objectivity of The Reader, There Will Be Blood shamelessly overexaggerates the stupidity of the congregation (and, believe me, I cannot believe I'm saying that since I generally believe Christianity to be silly). If Eli is proven to be a great fool, what then of the congregation who put such faith in him? It rubbed me the wrong way, but didn't make me enjoy the film less. Perhaps portraying Daniel as an empty, soul-less man is meant to counter the naivete of his enemy.

There will be blood. And there is. But despite this inevitable resolution, the film of this name is a philosophical take rather than a violent one on the turn-of-the-century oil business. The film, written and directed by the eccentric Paul Thomas Anderson, never stood out or set expectations for itself in my mind before I was able to watch it. Having seen it, it is very polarizing and remains controversial, to both myself and my peers. The basic summary is that an oil man named Daniel Plainview, an Oscar-winning role captured by actor Daniel Day-Lewis, develops a prosperous oil business but rejects his family for the sake of his own greed, leading to his mental deterioration. There's also a bit with an egotistical priest named Eli Sunday, played by Paul Dano. Overall, however, the movie is about deception, and its realistic consequences. On the most obvious level, Daniel cons gullible farmers out of their land so that he can drill for oil on it and become wealthy. Eli deceives his congregation by claiming to have divine powers of healing. Yet both of them fool themselves into thinking their respective ascensions to power are in and of themselves the single focus of their lives, neither realizing the implications of sacrificing their humanity for material success. 

The film centers around Daniel the character, and according to Anderson, it may not even have been made without the participation of Daniel the actor. Though the acting is what stems the vivid display of emotion we see on screen, the motivation behind his masquerades and rants is left to the script, which admittedly has a few holes in it. Plainview lusts for power, but the manners he uses to attain it are vague and unclear: he can smooth-talk his way into the pocketbooks of hundreds if not thousands of Western towns but has more than once resorted to trespassing and other blatantly illegal acts to get what he wants, when he wants. Worse still, the consequences of his sins don't come about until he straight up murders someone, and even then he gets little more than a slap in the face and a stern "Don't do it again." Meant to embody the worst aspects of capitalism in its ugliest hour, Daniel does his darndest to justify his efforts, though never in the least does he romanticize them. This internal struggle, a vital component of many great tragedies throughout history, is confused in this particular case by Daniel the character's refusal to open himself to the audience, even if Daniel the actor is more than willing. Every insight on Plainview's private affairs shows a sliver of evil within him, fostered by the much greater evil which surrounds him and threatens to consume him. One wonders if Plainview was ever good at all, and when all is laid bare at the end of Daniel's life, he has outlived not only his hope for redemption, but also any appearance of obligatory sympathy that awaited his feeble soul.

Where Daniel seeks acknowledgement in the solace of his immense fortune, Eli finds it in his audiences every week at his Church of the Third Revelation. Eli, in his worldly passion for fame, is stoked rather than tempered by the severity of his devoutness. Daniel, who either tramples on or ignores those who get in his way depending on their level of determination, finds his goal of staying at the Sunday ranch long enough to drill incompatible with Eli's repeated attempts to reform Daniel's personal demeanors. Eli, unable to prove his healing powers when Daniel's son H.W. goes deaf, slinks back in disgrace, envious of losing his ranch to a man even more persistent in gratification than he. In a sense, as Eli abandons his faith to reclaim the money he feels is his entitled right, he reenacts the great Biblical figures of betrayal. First, as Adam the first man, he falls to temptation and loses his Garden of Eden, his ranch. Next, as Cain the first murderer, his anger at God whom he cannot punish boils over into wrath upon the innocent Abel, the name of both the slain Biblical figure and Eli's own father. Lastly, as Judas the Fallen Apostle, he sells out his infinite saving grace for a finite sum of money, only to immediately regret his decision. Daniel's name also holds Biblical meaning, that of "judgment", which he enacts psychologically on the priest whose self-reputation is damaged irreparably. All these warped values acting as religious symbolism seem to stand for the corruption of the institutions both Daniel and Eli leaned on for their own sakes; to wit, Eli mistakes his secular desire for divine glory, and Daniel does the exact opposite.

Daniel's greatest sin, despite all his follies of fiscal frivolity, is underestimating the power of his own kin. Entering the cinematic stage without any relatives to help shape his destiny, Daniel reserves the choice to determine those he loves, and it is his own "judgment" which determines the fate of his new family. He chooses to adopt H.W. when the biological father is killed in a drilling accident, but this is only because Daniel sees the boy as an opportunity to create an extension of himself. H.W.'s cute face helps convince townsfolk to buy into his caretaker's schemes; Daniel envisions his protege as his most trusted partner, a tool to acquire more money. And when the tool breaks, Daniel can simply find a new one, as he does all the time in his various town-hopping political schemes. One of the oil gushers bursts H.W.'s eardrums, leaving him unable to communicate with his father, so Daniel sends him off to a special school to learn sign language. As H.W. remains an extension of Daniel, Daniel cannot simply abandon his child, but as the son goes to learn more about his new course of life, so the father contemplates this opportunity as well. He repeats this endeavor with a man who claims to be his brother, soon sharing with the newcomer how little he trusts the world around him. Before long, Daniel learns his partner is a fraud and puts him out of his life. It is therefore through the scope of others that Daniel's paradoxical actions can begin to be understood: H.W., the impostor, and everyone he's ever disadvantaged have just as much of a choice with their lives and the lives of others as Daniel has. This serves to illustrate the futility of Daniel's life: what he craved above all else was the ability to control, and he is most comprehensible when he loses his influence and pleas in an empty crusade to reclaim it. In this understanding also lies the film's greatest hope: H.W., despite his disability and the disowning his father lays before him, will not compromise in his resolve to live a happy, fruitful life under his own control. If the film broadcasts to a higher spectrum of those willing to listen, it capably shuns the mess of political or religious theater of the institutions in favor of the more wonderful mess of living life, and sets the denizens who value their human needs over their ephemeral wants on to chart their own destinations. Daniel, none the wiser, simply deceives himself by thinking there is any other way around this inalienable truth, resulting in his illusioned downfall and demonism at the end of his slippery slope.

As much as There will be blood focuses on the lies and deceit its own characters reek of, it also declares its own intentions clear as day, bypassing the conventional formulaic structure of the vast majority of movies to aim straight for the souls of the audience. Whether it hits or misses is up to the audience, and whether they choose to avert the message of the film. If one is seeking a good entertainment flick, this is the wrong film to watch. In terms of the storytelling, the script is patchy, but the emotion is present and prevalent. The motives of Daniel, Eli, H.W. and others may never be known for sure, but such is the way of life, and it is their choices that reflect who they are, changing or remaining resolute until death. What they choose is up to them, and it is up to each individual in the audience to decide whether they wish to deceive themselves or find the truth of life.

Paul Thomas Anderson is a director as well as a writer. His writing here is good but not great. The plot of this film is a miner, Daniel Plainview, who struck oil and became a rich man out of it, he then made it his business to drill and harvest the oil around America. His jackpot was this area in Little Boston, which had an "ocean full" of oil, and wanted to create a pipeline to the sea. There is also conflict and competition between Daniel and the preacher Eli Sunday. The film is like a rise and fall story of Daniel Plainview, at first we like him as he is just a poor man with nothing trying to scrape silver to gain some money and then as his ambition and empire grew, he became a horrible man obsessed with greed and power. The story is interesting and at times I think Daniel Plainview is similar to Barry Lyndon. For the most part it was interesting and entertaining but there are small moments where I felt the film just misfired, and that is the scenes with his brother. It is an important plot point as it shows a side Plainview we have never seen but I felt it wasn't executed well. The competition between Eli and Daniel was the best part of the film, to see whether who's ambition would win over the other. Both compete for the community's support either through Eli's faith and sermons or through Daniel's oil that could allow their city to flourish and gain in wealth. The climax is a moment that is driven through with just dialog but it was done really well that waiting 2 hours for it is worth it.

This is my first Paul Thomas Anderson film and I did have the bar set up high for this film. It didn't meet my expectations but it was good enough for me to want to venture into his other films, in particular The Master. I like the fact Anderson took the time to explore many areas in Plainview's life like his relationship with his son, his past, his struggles at the start. Anderson wanted this film to be slow and patient in order to flesh out the character enough and give us an impression that this man's personality and intentions have changed due to his greed and the crave of expansion.

Robert Elswit, the film's director of photography, has brought his style from Michael Clayton in this film. It takes it's time with shots allowing for performances to stand out more. The film also doesn't try to be flashy or pretty but rather just appropriate in the time period they are trying to create. I think the best moments that was captured on this film was the burning derrick scene. It was done beautifully and gives us an indicator that what lies ahead is not going to be good.

I was surprised to see that Jonny Greenwood did the score for this film. I've only really known him as the guitarist in Radiohead but he really made me take notice in this film. The music is eerie and dark, and sometimes quite simple. I like the fact that the film did not take a grand orchestra kind of feel and decided to keep it light and impactful.

The acting was one of the highlights of this film. I have never seen a film by Daniel Day Lewis before watching this and he played this tortured man well. The finest moment in the film for Lewis is the climax where he and Paul Dano (Eli) is driven by regret, anger and betrayal. Dano was great in the film, especially in his sermons where he lets it all out. The supporting cast were also good but the focus is really on the main two, and also Plainview's son (H.W. Plainview played by Dillon Freasier).

There Will Be Blood is a film that needs repeated viewings and requires patience in order to appreciate it. It contains strong performances and good cinematography and also an excellent score from Greenwood. Anderson's screenplay may have moments that I personally do not like but has enough gems in there to keep me entertained. I hope the next Paul Thomas Anderson film I watch impresses me a bit more than this.

There Will Be Blood may just be the most sincere, challenging and provocative examination of American capitalism since Orson Welles' Citizen Kane. Whereas the celebrated Welles masterpiece's starting point was the newspaper media, Theer Will Be Blood takes place in the early days of the oil business and the malevolent and crooked ways of the leading antihero, the power thirsty son of a gun Daniel Plainview. Paul Thomas Anderson's film is in fact an examination of evil and a comment on the beginnings of the corrosion of society and the corruption of moral standard. Yet, he initially allows the audience to be seduced by the central businessman figure Daniel Plainview, interpreted by Daniel Day-Lewis in yet another masterful performance as he transpires and embodies a deceitful and conniving type of restrained ferocity. On top of the study on the oil business, there is also an examination of the its contrast with religion through the preacher interpreted by Paul Dano. Yet, the two sides do not seem antagonistic, but rather both seem an equal threat. There Will Be Blood is a dark and thought provoking film that deepens and darkens through its pictorial cinematography, meticulous occasional use of visual metaphor and an intelligent and mature screenplay.

I remember when I first saw There Will Be Blood. It was about a month after the film came out on DVD in 2008 and my mother and I, on a whim, ordered the film On Demand just to see what it was. However, as the film progresses, this maybe one of the only few positive aspects of his personality.

Let's get this out of the way: There Will Be Blood is not a pleasant film. The title alone should state exactly what it is. It's the kind of movie that outright shows us the ugliness of people and does not look back. While the film does show some redeeming qualities in others in the form of love and to an extent kindness, we see the worst aspects of people all over the place. Our greed, anger, how we trick others in to doing what we want, deceit, lies, zealotry and quite a few more.
